author: Rozina Sabur
title: 'No more than three lettuce heads' supermarkets tell customers as extreme weather in Europe hits vegetables supplies
text:
09am 
S upermarkets have taken to rationing vegetables after extreme weather in the Mediterranean caused supply shortages. 
Shoppers have been venting their frustration on social media, sharing pictures of empty vegetable aisles during their trips to supermarkets. Supermarket rails against lettuce shortage rages pic.twitter.com/XbqDsd2pHH — Sara Neill (@ImSaraNeill) February 2, 2017 
S ome of the largest retailers are listing many popular vegetables as unavailable online in a bid to restrict supplies. 
While Tesco stores are also carrying a notice capping the number of lettuces customers can buy to just three per person. 
A spokesman for the supermarket said: "Due to bad weather conditions in Spain, we are experiencing some availability issues, but are working with our suppliers to resolve them as quickly as possible. 
"To make sure none of our customers miss out, we are asking them to limit the number of iceberg lettuces they buy to three." 
Morrisons has imposed a limit of three heads of broccoli and three iceberg lettuces per customer throughout its 492 stores, it has been reported. 
The shortage began with aubergines and courgettes in recent weeks and has now spread to other vegetables and salad items. you know the lettuce shortage is real when you pay £1.19 in @LidlUK for an iceberg — Gina Sherpa (@ginasherpa) February 2, 2017 
C ustomers are facing shortages of iceberg lettuce, baby spinach, mixed leaves, rocket, lollo rossa, cauliflower, broccoli, peppers, cucumbers and tomatoes. 
There are fears that supplies of some citrus fruits such as could be hit next, and the shortages may also fuel a rise in prices. 
Morrisons has also introduced a cap of three heads of broccoli and three iceberg lettuces to alleviate the issue, according to the Daily Mail . 
"As a result of the fact that the Spanish harvest has been very difficult this year, we have just about enough coming in to supply our customers," a spokesman told the paper. 
'We want to stop local tradespeople, restaurateurs, coming in and buying lots of stock. It is important that there is good availability for our customers." Follow Telegraph News
